summary: This section consists entirely of literary criticism and analysis of Jane Austen's Pride and Prejudice, written by George Saintsbury. The critic examines the novel's superior construction compared to Austen's other works, praising how elements like Lydia and Wickham's elopement connect naturally to the story's development. Saintsbury compares Austen's humor to Addison's, noting their shared qualities of subtlety, minuteness of touch, and a refined but ruthless delight in exposing folly. He provides detailed character analysis, particularly praising Mr. Collins as a masterpiece of satirical creation - a perfectly natural yet gigantic representation of 18th-century Philistinism, formality, and groveling respect for rank. The critic also analyzes Mr. Bennet's ironic wit as understandable given his situation with an irredeemably foolish wife, and defends the psychological realism of Darcy's character development. Elizabeth Bennet is celebrated as one of literature's most charming heroines, possessing wit, fearlessness, and natural disposition without any disagreeable qualities. The section concludes with a list of illustrations for the novel, suggesting this is a prefatory critical essay to an illustrated edition of Pride and Prejudice.

summary:
The initial section consisted of literary criticism by George Saintsbury analyzing Jane Austen's Pride and Prejudice, praising its construction and character development. The novel begins with Mrs. Bennet excitedly telling Mr. Bennet about wealthy bachelor Mr. Bingley renting nearby Netherfield Park. At the local assembly ball, Bingley proves charming and dances twice with beautiful Jane Bennet, while his proud friend Mr. Darcy offends everyone by refusing to dance and dismissing Elizabeth as merely 'tolerable.' When Jane receives an invitation to dine at Netherfield, Mrs. Bennet schemes to send her on horseback in threatening weather, hoping she'll be forced to stay overnight. The plan works—Jane gets caught in rain, falls ill, and must remain at Netherfield. Elizabeth walks three miles through muddy fields to nurse her sister, where social tensions emerge clearly. The Bingley sisters show their true colors by criticizing Elizabeth, while Darcy surprises everyone by defending her, revealing his growing attraction despite his earlier dismissiveness. During evening conversations, Elizabeth engages in witty debates about accomplished women, poetry, and character study, holding her own against Darcy and the Bingley sisters in intellectual sparring about pride, vanity, and their respective weaknesses. After several days, Elizabeth insists on leaving despite the Bingleys' polite requests to stay longer. Upon returning home, they receive the pompous clergyman Mr. Collins, who will inherit Longbourn due to the entail. Collins has come with the secret intention of marrying one of the Bennet daughters, initially choosing Jane but quickly switching to Elizabeth when Mrs. Bennet hints that Jane may soon be engaged. During a walk to Meryton, the party encounters the charming Mr. Wickham, a new officer who makes an excellent first impression. However, when Darcy and Bingley ride by, a mysterious and clearly hostile recognition passes between Darcy and Wickham, leaving Elizabeth burning with curiosity about their connection.

The situation takes dramatic turns when Collins proposes to Elizabeth, who firmly rejects him despite her mother's fury. In a stunning development, Charlotte Lucas accepts Collins's proposal the very next day, leaving Elizabeth devastated by her friend's mercenary decision to marry for security rather than love. Meanwhile, devastating news arrives from Miss Bingley announcing that the family has settled in London for the winter with no plans to return to Netherfield, heavily praising Miss Darcy and hinting at her expected union with Bingley, crushing Jane's hopes. Elizabeth suspects the Bingley sisters and Darcy of deliberately separating Bingley from Jane. Wickham's society becomes a welcome distraction at Longbourn, and he openly shares his grievances against Darcy, turning public opinion firmly against him. The Gardiners arrive for Christmas, bringing sensible counsel and offering to take Jane to London for a change of scene. Mrs. Gardiner warns Elizabeth about the imprudence of encouraging Wickham's attachment due to their mutual lack of fortune. Charlotte marries Collins and departs for Kent, while Jane's hopes are further crushed when Miss Bingley's cold behavior in London makes it clear she never valued their friendship and that Bingley has no intention of renewing his attentions. Wickham transfers his affections to the newly wealthy Miss King, which Elizabeth accepts with equanimity, realizing she was never truly in love with him. As March approaches, Elizabeth prepares to visit Charlotte at Hunsford, traveling with Sir William Lucas and his daughter Maria, with a planned stop in London to see Jane.

summary:
The novel follows the complex romantic entanglements of the Bennet family, particularly Elizabeth's evolving relationship with the proud Mr. Darcy. After initial mutual dislike, Elizabeth's prejudices against Darcy are shattered when she learns the truth about his character through his letter explaining his actions regarding Wickham and his intervention in separating Bingley from her sister Jane. During a visit to Pemberley with her aunt and uncle, Elizabeth encounters Darcy again and finds him transformed—gracious, humble, and eager to please her family. Her feelings shift from hatred to gratitude and growing love, especially after seeing his kindness to her relatives and learning of his past generosity.

The budding romance is devastated when Elizabeth receives news that her youngest sister Lydia has eloped with the villainous Wickham. Elizabeth is forced to reveal this family disgrace to Darcy, believing it will end any possibility of his regard for her. As she watches his shocked reaction and silent withdrawal, she realizes with painful clarity that she truly loves him just as all hope of happiness must be abandoned. She departs immediately with her aunt and uncle to return home, where they find the Bennet household in chaos. Mrs. Bennet blames everyone but herself while Mr. Bennet has gone to London to search for the fugitives. Elizabeth tortures herself with guilt, knowing she could have prevented the disaster by warning her family about Wickham's true character. The family clings to faint hope that Wickham might still marry Lydia, though Elizabeth knows his mercenary nature makes this unlikely without financial incentive.

summary:
The novel follows the complex romantic entanglements of the Bennet family, particularly Elizabeth's evolving relationship with the proud Mr. Darcy. After initial mutual dislike, Elizabeth's prejudices against Darcy were shattered when she learned the truth about his character through his letter explaining his actions regarding Wickham and his intervention in separating Bingley from her sister Jane. During a visit to Pemberley with her aunt and uncle, Elizabeth encountered Darcy again and found him transformed—gracious, humble, and eager to please her family. Her feelings shifted from hatred to gratitude and growing love, especially after seeing his kindness to her relatives and learning of his past generosity. The budding romance was devastated when Elizabeth received news that her youngest sister Lydia had eloped with the villainous Wickham. Elizabeth was forced to reveal this family disgrace to Darcy, believing it would end any possibility of his regard for her. The family crisis was resolved when it was revealed that Darcy had secretly orchestrated the entire rescue—tracking down the couple, negotiating with Wickham, paying over a thousand pounds in debts, and purchasing his commission.

Bingley returned to Netherfield accompanied by Darcy, leading to awkward encounters where Darcy appeared withdrawn despite Elizabeth's knowledge of his sacrifice. Through Mrs. Bennet's matchmaking schemes, Bingley was repeatedly left alone with Jane, and eventually proposed to her, bringing great joy to the family. However, Elizabeth's situation with Darcy remained unresolved as he maintained his distant behavior. The family celebration was dramatically interrupted when Lady Catherine de Bourgh arrived unexpectedly at Longbourn, having heard rumors of an engagement between Elizabeth and Darcy. In a heated confrontation during a walk in the garden, Lady Catherine demanded Elizabeth renounce any claim to her nephew, citing his supposed engagement to her daughter and Elizabeth's inferior social connections. Elizabeth boldly refused to promise anything, defending her right to marry whom she chose and dismissing Lady Catherine's threats about family disgrace and social ostracism. The encounter ended with Lady Catherine departing in anger, threatening to prevent the match, leaving Elizabeth anxious about what influence this interference might have on Darcy's feelings and future actions.

people.name: Elizabeth Bennet

people.name: Jane Bennet
people.description: Overwhelmed with joy at Bingley's proposal, rushing to tell her mother she 'would not trifle with her affectionate solicitude'; becomes 'the happiest creature in the world' and embraces Elizabeth with delight; glows with animation that makes her look handsomer than ever; receives her father's congratulations and blessing with gratitude; learns from Bingley that he was ignorant of her presence in London, confirming his sisters' interference; shows generous forgiveness toward the Bingley sisters despite their deception; constantly seeks Elizabeth's company to discuss her happiness when Bingley is absent

people.name: Bingley

people.name: Mrs. Bennet
people.description: Purposely breaks up card party to await news of Bingley's proposal; gives warm approval though talks of nothing else for half an hour; declares Jane her favorite child, forgetting all about Wickham and Lydia; boasts about Bingley's income of four or five thousand a year; claims she always knew the match would happen; privileges herself to whisper the engagement news to Mrs. Philips, leading to neighborhood gossip; receives Lady Catherine with utmost politeness despite being amazed by such an important visitor; boasts about her daughters and makes tactless comments about the family's recent changes

people.name: Mr. Bennet
people.description: Has short conference with Bingley about marrying Jane; joins family at supper with voice and manner showing his genuine happiness; congratulates Jane privately, calling her 'a good girl' and expressing pleasure in her happiness; teasingly warns the couple that their complying natures will lead to being cheated by servants and exceeding their income; spends pleasant morning shooting with Bingley, finding him agreeable with nothing presumptuous about him

people.name: Kitty Bennet
people.description: Sits upstairs with Mrs. Bennet when Jane comes to share the engagement news; simpers and smiles at the engagement celebration, hoping her turn will come soon; petitions for balls at Netherfield every winter once Jane is mistress there; present during Lady Catherine's visit, unknown to her but part of the family gathering

people.name: Mary Bennet
people.description: Petitions Jane for use of the library at Netherfield, hoping to benefit from her sister's advantageous marriage; seeks future advantages from Jane's position as mistress of a grand estate

people.name: Lady Catherine de Bourgh
people.description: Arrives unexpectedly at Longbourn in a chaise and four, entering with unusual ungraciousness; makes disparaging comments about the house and grounds; demands private conversation with Elizabeth to confront her about rumored engagement to Darcy; reveals she traveled from Rosings specifically to break up this supposed match; claims Darcy has been intended since infancy to marry her daughter Miss de Bourgh according to both mothers' wishes; becomes increasingly angry when Elizabeth refuses to promise to renounce Darcy; insults Elizabeth's family connections and brings up Lydia's scandal; threatens that Elizabeth will be censured and despised by Darcy's family; leaves in high dudgeon, vowing to carry her point and prevent the match

people.name: Miss de Bourgh
people.description: Lady Catherine's daughter, claimed to be engaged to Darcy since childhood according to the wishes of both their mothers; described as being destined for Darcy by voice of both families due to their noble lineage and splendid fortunes; the supposed obstacle to any match between Darcy and Elizabeth

people.name: Mrs. Philips

people.name: Wickham
people.description: Forgotten by Mrs. Bennet in her joy over Jane's engagement; described by Lady Catherine as 'son of Darcy's late father's steward' when she objects to him potentially becoming Darcy's brother-in-law; his low birth and scandalous marriage to Lydia used as arguments against Elizabeth's suitability for Darcy

people.name: Lydia Bennet
people.description: Temporarily forgotten by Mrs. Bennet who is absorbed in Jane's happiness; her 'infamous elopement' brought up by Lady Catherine as evidence of the Bennet family's unsuitability; described as having had a 'patched-up' marriage arranged at expense of father and uncle; her scandal used to argue against Elizabeth's worthiness to marry Darcy

people.name: Miss Bingley
people.description: Blamed by Bingley for his ignorance of Jane's presence in London; identified by Jane as being opposed to the match due to her brother's potential for more advantageous connections; Jane expresses hope for eventual reconciliation though acknowledging they can never return to their former intimacy; Elizabeth warns Jane not to be duped again by Miss Bingley's pretended regard

people.name: Elizabeth Bennet
people.description: Initially fears her father has received a letter from Lady Catherine about her confrontation; discovers it's actually from Mr. Collins warning about Darcy's supposed interest; endures her father's cruel mockery about Darcy's 'perfect indifference' toward her, which mortifies her deeply; courageously approaches Darcy during a walk to thank him for his help with Lydia; accepts his renewed proposal with joy after explaining how her feelings have completely changed; becomes engaged to Darcy and confides in Jane, though she dreads the family's reaction since no one but Jane likes him; must endure her mother's continued disparagement of Darcy while secretly being engaged to him

people.name: Mr. Darcy
people.description: Arrives at Longbourn with Bingley despite Lady Catherine's interference; walks with Elizabeth and Kitty initially, then alone with Elizabeth when Kitty leaves to visit Maria Lucas; surprised and touched when Elizabeth thanks him for his help with Lydia; explains he acted primarily for her sake rather than her family's; courageously proposes again, asking if her feelings have changed since his first proposal; expresses overwhelming happiness when she accepts him; reveals Lady Catherine's visit actually gave him hope since Elizabeth's frank nature would have led her to openly reject him if she were truly opposed; reflects on his past selfish behavior and credits Elizabeth with teaching him humility; explains his role in encouraging Bingley to pursue Jane and confessing his previous interference

people.name: Jane Bennet
people.description: Continues her happiness with Bingley; walks with him during the group outing, lagging behind with her fiancé; initially incredulous when Elizabeth reveals her engagement to Darcy, unable to believe someone who supposedly disliked him could now be engaged to him; questions whether Elizabeth truly loves Darcy and can be happy with him; expresses delight at the prospect of having Darcy as a brother-in-law and declares they will be among her dearest people; spends half the night in conversation learning all the details Elizabeth had previously kept secret about Pemberley and Darcy's role in Lydia's marriage

people.name: Elizabeth Bennet
people.description: Anxiously watches Darcy seek her father's permission for their engagement; successfully convinces her skeptical father of her genuine love by explaining her changed feelings and Darcy's good qualities; tells her mother about the engagement and endures her mercenary enthusiasm; playfully questions Darcy about how he first fell in love with her; writes joyfully to Mrs. Gardiner about her engagement; marries Darcy and becomes mistress of Pemberley; maintains close relationships with the Gardiners and helps her sister Georgiana understand marriage dynamics; occasionally provides financial assistance to the struggling Wickhams; persuades Darcy to reconcile with Lady Catherine

people.name: Mr. Darcy
people.description: Successfully obtains Mr. Bennet's consent for Elizabeth's hand in marriage; explains to Elizabeth that he fell in love gradually and was attracted to her liveliness and impertinence because it differed from the obsequious attention of other women; reveals his real purpose in returning to Netherfield was to see Elizabeth and judge if she could love him; writes to inform Lady Catherine of his engagement; marries Elizabeth and brings her to Pemberley; patiently endures the vulgarity of Elizabeth's relatives during their courtship; continues to assist Wickham professionally for Elizabeth's sake though never receives him at Pemberley; eventually reconciles with Lady Catherine at Elizabeth's persuasion; develops genuine affection for the Gardiners

people.name: Jane Bennet
people.description: Marries Bingley and initially lives at Netherfield for a year before moving to an estate in a neighboring county to Derbyshire to be within thirty miles of Elizabeth; occasionally applied to by the Wickhams for financial assistance; serves as a positive influence on Kitty's improvement; receives and kindly answers an insincere congratulatory letter from Miss Bingley; the Wickhams frequently stay with the Bingleys, sometimes overstaying their welcome

people.name: Bingley
people.description: Marries Jane and lives at Netherfield for only a year before purchasing an estate in a neighboring county to Derbyshire, wanting distance from Mrs. Bennet and Meryton relations; his good humor is eventually tested by the Wickhams' frequent and prolonged visits, leading him to hint they should leave; receives insincere congratulations from his sister Miss Bingley on his marriage

people.name: Mrs. Bennet
people.description: Initially speechless upon hearing of Elizabeth's engagement to Darcy, then becomes ecstatic about his wealth and status, immediately focusing on his ten thousand a year income and planning their wedding; stands in such awe of Darcy that she barely speaks to him except to show deference; continues to be nervous and silly throughout her life despite her daughters' successful marriages; eventually gets rid of her two most deserving daughters through marriage; unable to sit alone, requiring Mary's constant company

people.name: Mr. Bennet
people.description: Initially incredulous about Elizabeth's engagement to Darcy, questioning if she's out of her senses and reminding her of her former hatred; warns her against an unequal marriage where she couldn't respect her husband; eventually convinced by Elizabeth's passionate defense of Darcy and grants his consent; amazed to learn of Darcy's role in Lydia's marriage; takes pains to get acquainted with Darcy and grows to esteem him; jokes about preferring Wickham among his sons-in-law; writes a brief, sardonic note to Mr. Collins about Elizabeth's engagement; misses Elizabeth greatly and frequently visits Pemberley; refuses to let Kitty visit the Wickhams

people.name: Kitty Bennet
people.description: Spends most of her time with her two elder married sisters and improves greatly in superior society, becoming less irritable, ignorant, and insipid; not as ungovernable as Lydia and benefits from being removed from her bad influence; prevented by her father from visiting the Wickhams despite their invitations promising balls and young men

people.name: Mary Bennet
people.description: Remains at home as the only daughter still living with her parents; forced to abandon her pursuit of accomplishments to keep Mrs. Bennet company since she cannot sit alone; obliged to mix more with the world through morning visits, though she still moralizes over them; no longer mortified by comparisons to her sisters' beauty and suspected by her father to accept the changes without much reluctance

people.name: Lady Catherine de Bourgh
people.description: Becomes extremely indignant upon learning of Darcy's engagement and sends him an abusive reply, especially attacking Elizabeth, ending all intercourse temporarily; eventually her resentment gives way to either affection for Darcy or curiosity about Elizabeth's conduct as his wife; condescends to visit them at Pemberley despite considering it polluted by Elizabeth's presence and her trade connections; reconciles with the couple after Elizabeth's persuasion

people.name: Mr. Collins
people.description: Comes to Lucas Lodge with Charlotte to escape Lady Catherine's anger over Darcy's engagement; subjects Darcy to parading and obsequious civility during their visit, which Darcy bears with admirable calmness; receives Mr. Bennet's sardonic note about Elizabeth's engagement advising him to console Lady Catherine but stand by the nephew who has more to give

people.name: Charlotte Collins
people.description: Genuinely rejoices in Elizabeth's engagement to Darcy; anxious to escape to Lucas Lodge until Lady Catherine's storm over the engagement blows over; her arrival provides sincere pleasure to Elizabeth despite the awkwardness of Mr. Collins's behavior around Darcy

people.name: Mrs. Philips
people.description: Her vulgarity taxes Darcy's forbearance during the engagement period; though she stands in awe of him and speaks less familiarly than she does with Bingley, she remains vulgar whenever she does speak, and her respect doesn't make her more elegant

people.name: Wickham
people.description: Bears with philosophy the knowledge that Elizabeth now knows the full extent of his ingratitude and falsehood; still hopes Darcy might be prevailed upon to make his fortune; lives an unsettled, extravagant lifestyle with Lydia, always moving in search of cheaper situations while spending more than they should; his affection for Lydia soon sinks into indifference; enjoys himself in London or Bath while Lydia visits her sisters; continues to be assisted professionally by Darcy for Elizabeth's sake, though never received at Pemberley

people.name: Lydia Bennet
people.description: Writes to Elizabeth congratulating her on her marriage and immediately asking for financial help, hoping Wickham might get a court position worth three or four hundred a year; continues her extravagant lifestyle with Wickham, frequently changing residences and overspending; her affection for Wickham lasts longer than his for her; occasionally visits Pemberley when Wickham is away, and frequently stays with the Bingleys, sometimes to their annoyance; carefully kept from influencing Kitty further

people.name: Miss Bingley
people.description: Deeply mortified by Darcy's marriage but drops her resentment to retain visiting rights at Pemberley; becomes fonder than ever of Georgiana, almost as attentive to Darcy as before, and pays off every arrear of civility to Elizabeth; writes affectionate but insincere congratulations to her brother on his marriage and even writes to Jane expressing delight and former professions of regard

people.name: Mrs. Gardiner
people.description: Receives a joyful letter from Elizabeth announcing her engagement and expressing gratitude for not going to the Lakes, since that trip brought her to Pemberley; invited to spend Christmas at Pemberley; maintains the most intimate terms with both Darcy and Elizabeth after their marriage, with both feeling warmest gratitude toward the Gardiners for bringing Elizabeth into Derbyshire and thus uniting them

people.name: Georgiana Darcy
people.description: Expresses sincere delight in four pages about Elizabeth's engagement and her earnest desire to be loved by her as a sister; makes Pemberley her home after Darcy's marriage; develops exactly the attachment with Elizabeth that Darcy hoped for, loving each other as well as intended; initially astonished by Elizabeth's lively, sportive manner of talking to Darcy but learns from Elizabeth's instruction that a wife may take liberties with her husband that a much younger sister cannot; receives renewed attention from Miss Bingley after the marriage

people.name: Sir William Lucas
people.description: Subjects Darcy to obsequious civility during the Collinses' visit, complimenting him on carrying away the brightest jewel of the country and expressing hopes of meeting at St. James's, which Darcy bears with decent composure though he shrugs his shoulders once Sir William is out of sight

places.name: Longbourn
places.description: Setting for Elizabeth's anxious wait during Darcy's conversation with her father; where she convinces Mr. Bennet of her genuine feelings and tells Mrs. Bennet about the engagement; site of their courtship period where Elizabeth tries to shield Darcy from her vulgar relatives; home where Mary remains as the only unmarried daughter to keep Mrs. Bennet company

places.name: Netherfield
places.description: Bingley and Jane's first home after marriage, which they occupy for only one year before moving to be closer to the Darcys; frequently hosts the Wickhams' prolonged visits that test even Bingley's good humor

places.name: Pemberley
places.description: Darcy's estate that becomes Elizabeth's home after marriage and Georgiana's permanent residence; destination for Elizabeth's joyful letter promising visits from the Gardiners at Christmas; where the sisters develop their close relationship; visited by Lady Catherine despite her initial outrage; never receives Wickham as a guest though Lydia occasionally visits when he's away; represents comfort and elegance that Elizabeth looks forward to during their courtship

places.name: Lucas Lodge
places.description: Where the Collinses retreat to escape Lady Catherine's anger over Darcy's engagement; site of Charlotte's visit that brings Elizabeth pleasure despite Mr. Collins's obsequious behavior toward Darcy

places.name: Derbyshire
places.description: County containing Pemberley where Elizabeth makes her home; the neighboring county where Bingley purchases an estate to be within thirty miles of the Darcys, fulfilling his sisters' darling wish to leave Hertfordshire; represents the superior society where Kitty spends time and improves

places.name: London
places.description: Where Wickham goes to enjoy himself while Lydia visits her sisters; represents the fashionable life that Mrs. Bennet envisions for Elizabeth as Mrs. Darcy with a house in town

places.name: Bath
places.description: Another destination where Wickham goes to enjoy himself while leaving Lydia to visit her sisters

places.name: St. James's
places.description: Court location mentioned by Sir William Lucas in his obsequious hopes of meeting the Darcys there in fashionable society

open_threads.description: Elizabeth's relationship with Darcy, successfully resolved through marriage and their happy life together at Pemberley
Jane and Bingley's relationship, successfully resolved through marriage and their move to Derbyshire to be near the Darcys
Lady Catherine's opposition to Elizabeth and Darcy's match, resolved through her eventual reconciliation and visits to Pemberley
Elizabeth's anxiety about family reactions to her engagement, resolved through successful conversations with her parents and their acceptance of the match
